quiz_title: Constitutional Bodies of India - Comprehensive Quiz
description: A comprehensive quiz covering India's Constitutional Bodies, their roles, functions, and importance in democracy using relatable analogies.

questions.question: Which body acts as the 'referee' of Indian democracy by conducting elections?
questions.explanation: The Election Commission of India acts as the referee of democracy, organizing and conducting fair elections to the Lok Sabha, state assemblies, and offices of President and Vice President.
questions.analogy: Like a sports referee who ensures fair play during games

questions.question: The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) only checks government accounts but cannot take any action against misuse of funds.
questions.explanation: While CAG cannot directly punish officials, it audits government spending and reports to Parliament and state legislatures. These reports are examined by committees like the Public Accounts Committee (PAC), which summons officials and recommends corrective actions.
questions.analogy: Like a school teacher checking project expenses and reporting to the principal for action

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body follows a three-stage examination process similar to school trials?
questions.explanation: UPSC conducts the Civil Services Examination in three stages: Preliminary (screening), Mains (depth), and Personality Test (interview), followed by document and medical verification.
questions.analogy: Like school football trials with skills tests, practical exams, and coach interviews

questions.question: A political party wants to distribute freebies during election campaigning. Which body and principle would prevent this?
questions.explanation: The ECI enforces the Model Code of Conduct (MCC) which prohibits misuse of government schemes and resources during elections to ensure fair campaigning.
questions.analogy: Like a sports committee preventing teams from using unfair advantages during matches

questions.question: A school received funds to build a library but the actual building is half the promised size with poor quality materials. Which Constitutional Body's approach would be similar to how this issue would be handled?
questions.explanation: CAG checks whether government projects and expenses are supported by proper records and whether money was spent on the right things in the right way, similar to verifying if school funds were used correctly for the library.
questions.analogy: Like a teacher checking if library funds were properly used and the building was built as promised

questions.question: Which body acts as an 'ombudsman' for corruption complaints against public officials?
questions.explanation: Lokpal (central level) and Lokayuktas (state level) act as ombudsmen - neutral authorities who receive complaints, conduct inquiries, and can grant sanction for prosecution against public officials.
questions.analogy: Like a neighborhood watch committee that investigates complaints fairly

questions.question: In a family council, who would represent the role of the Finance Commission?
options: The person who checks the family budget
The person who selects new family members
The person who resolves family conflicts
questions.explanation: Finance Commission decides how tax revenues are shared between centre and states, like a family council dividing shared resources fairly so everyone gets an appropriate slice.
questions.analogy: Like a fair divider for shared resources in a family budget meeting

questions.question: Which stage of UPSC examination primarily tests ethical judgment, communication, and suitability?
questions.explanation: Personality Test (Interview) assesses judgment, communication, ethics, and suitability for public service - how well a candidate handles real-life situations with integrity.
questions.analogy: Like a coach's interview to check teamwork and attitude after technical trials

questions.question: State Public Service Commissions work exactly like UPSC but only for state government jobs.
questions.explanation: SPSCs work like the UPSC for state-level jobs, ensuring merit-based recruitment in state governments. They mirror the central commission's role at the state level.
questions.analogy: Like local talent scouts compared to national talent selectors

questions.question: If a student accused another of taking their lunch money, which Constitutional Body's process would this be similar to?
questions.explanation: Lokpal/Lokayuktas form a fair committee to listen, investigate, and recommend action - similar to how a class committee would handle the lunch money complaint fairly.
questions.analogy: Like a playground complaint committee that follows rules and hears both sides

questions.question: What is the primary focus of the Model Code of Conduct (MCC) during elections?
questions.explanation: MCC ensures peaceful campaigning, no misuse of government schemes for votes, policy-based criticism, and orderly conduct on polling day to keep elections fair and democratic.
questions.analogy: Like a school code of conduct ensuring fair play during class elections

questions.question: A government project was completed but audit reports showed money was spent on unauthorized items. What accountability process would follow?
questions.explanation: CAG reports are examined by the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) which summons officials, asks questions, and recommends actions - creating accountability for spending irregularities.
questions.analogy: Like a family council reviewing expenses and demanding explanations for unauthorized purchases

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body ensures that government jobs are filled based on merit, not favoritism?
questions.explanation: UPSC selects civil servants through merit-based, transparent, multi-stage examinations that assess knowledge, clarity of thinking, communication, and ethical judgment.
questions.analogy: Like a fair talent selection committee choosing best candidates based on skills, not connections

questions.question: In a school administration, who would represent the UPSC's role?
questions.explanation: UPSC acts like a fair teacher who evaluates students transparently and merit-based, ensuring capable and honest people enter public service.
questions.analogy: Like a fair teacher who evaluates students based on merit and transparent criteria

questions.question: The CAG only audits central government accounts and has no role in state government finances.
questions.explanation: CAG audits government accounts at central, state, and even public sector undertakings, ensuring every rupee is accounted for and used as the law intends at all levels.
questions.analogy: Like a teacher checking both individual student projects and class-wide activities

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body maintains the official list of eligible voters?
questions.explanation: ECI prepares and maintains the electoral roll - the official list of eligible voters - and works to keep it accurate and inclusive before elections.
questions.analogy: Like maintaining a class roster to ensure only eligible students participate in voting

questions.question: A government official is accused of corruption. Which body would first receive and evaluate the complaint?
questions.explanation: Lokpal/Lokayuktas act as ombudsmen who receive complaints, conduct preliminary inquiries, and can order investigations against public officials.
questions.analogy: Like a neighborhood watch committee that first receives and evaluates complaints

questions.question: During its first five years, what percentage of Lokpal complaints were rejected due to incorrect formatting?
questions.explanation: Nearly 90% of complaints were rejected due to incorrect formatting, though 2,320 defect-free complaints were registered and processed during this period.
questions.analogy: Like a school committee rejecting projects that don't follow submission guidelines

questions.question: What does the Finance Commission recommend?
options: How to share revenue between centre and states
questions.explanation: Finance Commission decides how tax revenues are shared between the centre and states, like a fair divider for shared resources so everyone gets an appropriate slice.
questions.analogy: Like a family meeting deciding how to fairly divide the monthly budget

questions.question: In a neighborhood watch system, which Constitutional Body's role would be most similar?
questions.explanation: Lokpal acts like a neighborhood watch committee - receiving complaints, investigating fairly, and recommending action while maintaining neutrality.
questions.analogy: Like a neighborhood watch that investigates complaints fairly and recommends actions

questions.question: The UPSC Civil Services Examination includes a medical test because some government jobs require specific physical fitness.
questions.explanation: Medical Examination ensures candidates are physically and mentally fit for role-specific demands, completing the merit-based selection process.
questions.analogy: Like sports teams checking fitness after technical trials for safety

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body's reports are reviewed by the Public Accounts Committee (PAC)?
questions.explanation: CAG submits audit reports to Parliament and state legislatures. Members examine these reports in committees like the PAC, which summons officials to explain irregularities.
questions.analogy: Like a principal reviewing the teacher's audit report and calling students to explain issues

questions.question: A political candidate wants to use government hospitals to show their achievements during campaigns. Which body would prevent this?
questions.explanation: ECI's Model Code of Conduct prohibits misuse of government schemes and resources for electoral gains, ensuring fair campaigning.
questions.analogy: Like preventing teams from using school facilities for personal promotion during elections

questions.question: Which famous audit findings by CAG led to major parliamentary debates and further actions?
questions.explanation: CAG flagged serious irregularities in 2G spectrum allocation and coal block allocations, leading to debates in Parliament and further actions by law enforcement agencies.
questions.analogy: Like a teacher's audit uncovering problems with major school projects

questions.question: What is the main characteristic of merit-based selection by UPSC?
options: Selection based on ability, knowledge, and performance
questions.explanation: Merit-based means selection depends on what a candidate knows and how well they can apply it, not on personal connections or shortcuts.
questions.analogy: Like choosing the best football players based on skills and performance, not who they know

questions.question: In a sports committee, who represents the ECI's role?
questions.explanation: ECI acts as a referee in the democratic process, enforcing rules, managing the process, and ensuring every participant (party/candidate) plays fairly.
questions.analogy: Like a sports referee ensuring fair play in democratic games

questions.question: Lokpal can directly punish corrupt officials without any further legal processes.
questions.explanation: Lokpal can order inquiries and grant sanction for prosecution, but actual punishment requires legal processes in courts. It ensures fair investigation, not direct punishment.
questions.analogy: Like a committee that recommends action but cannot directly punish - legal processes follow

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body trains election officials and plans logistics for millions of polling stations?
questions.explanation: ECI trains election officials, plans logistics for millions of polling stations, and ensures orderly queues and safe access for all voters on election day.
questions.analogy: Like organizing and training volunteers for a large school event

questions.question: A state government wants to recruit teachers for state schools. Which Constitutional Body would handle this process?
questions.explanation: State Public Service Commissions (SPSC) work like the UPSC for state-level jobs, ensuring merit-based recruitment in state governments.
questions.analogy: Like local talent scouts organizing trials for state-level teams

questions.question: How many Lokpal probes were ordered and prosecution sanctions granted in its first five years?
questions.explanation: In its first five years, Lokpal ordered 24 probes and granted prosecution sanction in 6 cases, showing careful and measured approach to corruption complaints.
questions.analogy: Like a committee carefully investigating complaints before recommending actions

questions.question: What is the primary function of the UPSC Preliminary Examination?
questions.explanation: Preliminary Examination tests basic knowledge and aptitude to screen candidates for the next round - like a quick quiz to identify promising candidates.
questions.analogy: Like a preliminary skills test to shortlist candidates for detailed evaluation

questions.question: In a family budget meeting, who would represent the CAG's role?
options: Person who audits expenses and reports
questions.explanation: CAG acts like a family auditor who checks expenses, verifies receipts, and reports to the family council (legislature) about spending irregularities.
questions.analogy: Like a family member who audits expenses and reports to the family council

questions.question: The Finance Commission only deals with central government finances and has no role in state budgets.
questions.explanation: Finance Commission decides how tax revenues are shared between the centre and states, ensuring both central and state needs are met fairly.
questions.analogy: Like a family budget that considers both household needs and individual allowances

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body ensures that election results are declared openly and transparently?
questions.explanation: ECI ensures transparent counting and declares results openly, building trust that outcomes reflect fair processes even when preferences differ.
questions.analogy: Like a referee announcing match results transparently after fair play

questions.question: A government project was completed but many citizens doubt if it was built as promised. Which body would investigate this?
questions.explanation: CAG audits government projects and expenses, checking whether money was spent on the right things in the right way and if projects were completed as promised.
questions.analogy: Like a school auditor checking if library construction matched the promised design

questions.question: What does 'defect-free complaints' mean in Lokpal context?
options: Complaints that follow proper format and procedures
questions.explanation: Defect-free complaints are those that follow proper format and procedures as required by law - 2,320 such complaints were registered in the first five years.
questions.analogy: Like school projects that follow all submission guidelines properly

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body's work is described as 'beginning of accountability, not the end'?
questions.explanation: CAG audits are the beginning of accountability. Reports trigger legislative review (PAC), executive actions, and system improvements to prevent recurrence.
questions.analogy: Like a teacher's audit that starts the accountability process, not ends it

questions.question: In a school sports team selection, who represents the UPSC's role?
questions.explanation: UPSC acts like a fair coach who conducts trials, interviews, and verification to select the best candidates based on merit and transparent rules.
questions.analogy: Like a fair coach selecting team members based on transparent trials and interviews

questions.question: The Lokpal only investigates complaints against central government officials.
questions.explanation: Lokpal handles complaints at the central level while Lokayuktas handle them at state level. Together they cover the entire government structure.
questions.analogy: Like having both school-level and district-level complaint committees

questions.question: What does the UPSC Mains Examination primarily test?
questions.explanation: Mains Examination tests deep understanding and clear writing through long-answer questions that explain ideas in detail.
questions.analogy: Like comprehensive exams that test detailed understanding, not just basic knowledge

questions.question: During elections, political parties should criticize based on what according to the Model Code of Conduct?
questions.explanation: MCC emphasizes criticism based on work and policies, not personal identity or religion, keeping elections focused on performance.
questions.analogy: Like debating what a student accomplished, not who they are personally

questions.question: How many defect-free complaints were registered by Lokpal in its first five years?
questions.explanation: 2,320 defect-free complaints were registered and processed during Lokpal's first five years of operation.
questions.analogy: Like a committee receiving many complaint forms, with 2,320 properly filled ones

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body ensures peaceful campaigning and orderly voting?
questions.explanation: ECI enforces the Model Code of Conduct which includes peaceful campaigning and orderly conduct on polling day to ensure free and fair elections.
questions.analogy: Like a teacher ensuring peaceful behavior during class elections

questions.question: In a neighborhood council, who represents the Finance Commission's role?
options: Person who allocates community resources fairly
questions.explanation: Finance Commission acts like a neighborhood council that fairly allocates shared community resources between different areas and needs.
questions.analogy: Like a council fairly dividing community resources and neighborhood budgets

questions.question: The CAG only checks if government spending was legal, not whether it achieved good value for money.
questions.explanation: CAG audits verify two things: 1) legality (was spending allowed by law), and 2) value for money (did it achieve intended results without waste).
questions.analogy: Like checking both whether expenses were allowed AND whether they delivered good results

questions.question: What is the main purpose of UPSC document verification?
questions.explanation: Document Verification ensures eligibility and authenticity by checking that age, education, and certificates are genuine and meet requirements.
questions.analogy: Like checking student records to ensure all certificates are genuine before final selection

questions.question: A government scheme is being misused for electoral gains. Which body's principle would prevent this?
questions.explanation: ECI's Model Code of Conduct prohibits misuse of government schemes for votes, ensuring public resources are not used for electoral benefits.
questions.analogy: Like preventing teams from using unfair advantages during competition

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body 'summons officials to explain irregularities' after audit reports?
questions.explanation: Public Accounts Committee (PAC) reviews CAG reports and summons officials to explain irregularities and suggest corrective actions.
questions.analogy: Like a principal calling students to explain issues found in the audit report

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body acts as the 'fairness team' of democracy?
questions.explanation: Constitutional bodies together form the 'fairness team' - the referee (ECI), watchdog (CAG), honest judges (UPSC), and umpire (Lokpal) protecting fairness and honesty in government.
questions.analogy: Like a team of referees, judges, and umpires working together for fair play

questions.question: In a school library project, who represents the CAG's role?
options: Teacher who audits expenses and verifies building
questions.explanation: CAG acts like a teacher who audits library project expenses, checks if money was used correctly, and verifies that the library was built as promised.
questions.analogy: Like a teacher checking library project costs and verifying what was actually built

questions.question: The Lokpal and Lokayuktas are the same body working at different levels.
questions.explanation: Lokpal works at central level while Lokayuktas work at state level, but both function as ombudsmen for anti-corruption complaints.
questions.analogy: Like having the same type of committee at school level and district level

questions.question: What is the primary focus of UPSC's Personality Test?
questions.explanation: Personality Test assesses judgment, communication, ethics, and suitability for public service - how well candidates handle real-life situations with integrity.
questions.analogy: Like a final interview checking attitude and ethics, not just technical skills

questions.question: A student doubts if school election votes were counted fairly. Which body would ensure transparent counting?
options: ECI conducting and counting votes transparently
questions.explanation: ECI ensures transparent counting and declares results openly, building trust that the process was fair even if some students' preferred candidate didn't win.
questions.analogy: Like a teacher counting votes openly so everyone trusts the class election results

questions.question: How many Lokpal prosecution sanctions were granted in the first five years?
questions.explanation: Lokpal granted prosecution sanction in 6 cases during its first five years, showing careful consideration before recommending prosecution.
questions.analogy: Like a committee carefully deciding when to recommend serious actions

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body protects public money from waste and misuse?
questions.explanation: CAG protects public money by auditing government spending, checking legality and value for money, and reporting to legislatures for accountability.
questions.analogy: Like a vigilant guardian watching over community funds

questions.question: In a family committee handling disputes, who represents the Lokpal's role?
questions.explanation: Lokpal acts like a neutral committee member who receives complaints, investigates fairly, and recommends action while remaining impartial.
questions.analogy: Like a neutral family committee member investigating complaints fairly

questions.question: The Finance Commission decides how to share revenue between different states.
questions.explanation: Finance Commission recommends both vertical (centre to states) and horizontal (among states) revenue sharing, ensuring equitable distribution.
questions.analogy: Like fairly dividing shared resources among different family members based on needs

questions.question: What ensures that every eligible citizen can cast their vote without fear or favor?
questions.explanation: ECI ensures every eligible citizen can cast their vote without fear or favor by maintaining fair processes, training officials, and ensuring orderly voting.
questions.analogy: Like a referee ensuring every player can participate fairly in the game

questions.question: A government hospital was built but citizens doubt its quality. Which body would investigate this concern?
questions.explanation: CAG would audit the hospital project's expenses and construction quality, checking if money was spent properly and if the hospital meets standards.
questions.analogy: Like a teacher auditing school building project to ensure quality and proper spending

questions.question: What percentage of Lokpal complaints were from central bodies in the first five years?
questions.explanation: 35% of complaints were against central bodies, showing the broad scope of Lokpal's jurisdiction over various government institutions.
questions.analogy: Like a committee receiving complaints about different types of institutions

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body ensures that public servants are capable and honest?
questions.explanation: UPSC ensures capable and honest public servants through merit-based, multi-stage selection that assesses knowledge, skills, and ethical judgment.
questions.analogy: Like a fair selection committee choosing capable and honest people for important roles

questions.question: In a school playground, who represents the ECI's role during elections?
questions.explanation: ECI acts like a teacher ensuring everyone votes safely and counts fairly, like supervising class elections.
questions.analogy: Like a teacher supervising class elections to ensure fair and peaceful voting

questions.question: The UPSC only recruits for central government jobs, not state government positions.
questions.explanation: UPSC recruits for central civil services while State Public Service Commissions recruit for state civil services, covering the entire government structure.
questions.analogy: Like having separate selectors for national and state teams

questions.question: What is the final stage in UPSC's selection process?
questions.explanation: Medical Examination is the final stage, ensuring candidates are physically and mentally fit for role-specific demands before final appointment.
questions.analogy: Like final fitness check before joining a professional sports team

questions.question: During elections, parties should focus criticism on what according to democratic principles?
questions.explanation: Democratic elections should focus on work and policies, not personal attacks or identity, keeping the contest about performance and ideas.
questions.analogy: Like debating a student's academic performance rather than personal characteristics

questions.question: What happens after CAG audit reports are tabled in Parliament?
options: PAC reviews them and summons officials
questions.explanation: Public Accounts Committee (PAC) reviews CAG reports, summons officials to explain irregularities, and recommends corrective actions.
questions.analogy: Like a principal reviewing the teacher's audit and calling students to explain issues

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body builds public trust by ensuring fair processes?
questions.explanation: All constitutional bodies together build public trust by protecting fairness and honesty in government - the referee, watchdog, honest judges, and umpire working collectively.
questions.analogy: Like a complete team of officials ensuring fair play in all aspects of the game

questions.question: In a school project team, who represents the Finance Commission's role?
questions.explanation: Finance Commission acts like a team member who fairly allocates shared resources among different parts of the project based on needs and equity.
questions.analogy: Like fairly dividing project resources among different team members

questions.question: The Lokpal can investigate complaints against any public official, including ministers.
questions.explanation: Lokpal has jurisdiction over public officials including ministers and MPs, as shown by the 3% of complaints against ministers/MPs in the first five years.
questions.analogy: Like a committee that can investigate complaints against any team member, including leaders

questions.question: What ensures that election campaigning is peaceful and orderly?
questions.explanation: Model Code of Conduct ensures peaceful campaigning, no threats or violence, and orderly conduct during elections.
questions.analogy: Like a code of conduct for students to ensure peaceful behavior during events

questions.question: A citizen wants to complain about a government official's corruption. Which body would handle this complaint?
questions.explanation: Lokpal/Lokayuktas act as ombudsmen who receive complaints, conduct inquiries, and can grant sanction for prosecution against public officials.
questions.analogy: Like a complaint committee that receives and evaluates concerns about officials

questions.question: What was the operational period for the Lokpal statistics mentioned?
questions.explanation: The statistics refer to Lokpal's first five years of operation since March 2019, during which it ordered 24 probes and granted 6 prosecution sanctions.
questions.analogy: Like reviewing a committee's performance over its first five years of operation

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body verifies that government projects achieve intended results?
questions.explanation: CAG audits verify both legality and value for money - whether projects achieved intended results without waste, like checking if a library was built properly.
questions.analogy: Like checking if a school project achieved its goals, not just if expenses were legal

questions.question: In a family dispute resolution, who represents the CAG's role?
options: Family member checking expenses and reporting
questions.explanation: CAG acts like a family member who checks expenses, verifies receipts, and reports to the family council about any irregularities.
questions.analogy: Like a family member who audits expenses and reports to the family council

questions.question: The Finance Commission makes decisions based on political preferences rather than equitable principles.
questions.explanation: Finance Commission works on principles of equity, needs, fiscal capacity, and balanced development, not political preferences, to ensure fair resource sharing.
questions.analogy: Like dividing family resources based on needs and fairness, not personal preferences

questions.question: What is the main benefit of UPSC's multi-stage examination process?
options: It ensures fair and comprehensive assessment
questions.explanation: Multi-stage process (Prelims, Mains, Interview, verification, medical) ensures fair and comprehensive assessment of different skills and qualities.
questions.analogy: Like multiple rounds of trials ensuring comprehensive evaluation of all skills

questions.question: During elections, what should parties avoid using for electoral gains?
questions.explanation: Model Code of Conduct prohibits misuse of government schemes and resources for electoral gains, ensuring fair competition.
questions.analogy: Like preventing teams from using school resources for personal promotion

questions.question: What happens if a Lokpal complaint is incomplete or wrong in format?
options: It is sent to another committee
questions.explanation: If a complaint is incomplete or wrong in format, it cannot be processed - similar to how a school project cannot be graded until all pages are complete.
questions.analogy: Like a school project that cannot be graded until all required pages are submitted properly

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body's work prevents 'repeat mistakes' in government?
questions.explanation: CAG audit cycle includes accountability steps where corrective actions are initiated and systems are improved to prevent mistakes from happening again.
questions.analogy: Like a teacher who not only finds errors but ensures they don't happen again

questions.question: In a school sports competition, who represents the UPSC's role?
questions.explanation: UPSC acts like fair judges who evaluate candidates through multiple rounds, ensuring the best are selected based on merit.
questions.analogy: Like fair judges evaluating performances in multiple rounds to select winners

questions.question: The CAG only audits central government accounts and has no jurisdiction over state governments.
questions.explanation: CAG audits government accounts at both central and state levels, and even public sector undertakings, ensuring accountability across all levels.
questions.analogy: Like a teacher checking both class projects and individual student work

questions.question: What ensures that candidates selected by UPSC are genuinely qualified?
questions.explanation: Document verification ensures eligibility and authenticity by checking that age, education, and certificates are genuine before final selection.
questions.analogy: Like checking all student certificates are genuine before final team selection

questions.question: A government road project was completed but is already damaged. Which body would investigate this issue?
questions.explanation: CAG would audit the road project, checking if money was spent properly and if quality standards were met, investigating poor construction.
questions.analogy: Like a teacher auditing a construction project to check if it was built to proper standards

questions.question: What percentage of Lokpal complaints were against Group A-D officials?
questions.explanation: 21% of Lokpal complaints were against Group A-D officials, showing coverage across different government employee categories.
questions.analogy: Like a committee receiving complaints about different types of officials and employees

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body acts as a 'neutral umpire' in democracy?
questions.explanation: All constitutional bodies act as neutral umpires - ECI in elections, CAG in spending, UPSC in hiring, and Lokpal in complaints - each protecting fairness.
questions.analogy: Like having different umpires for different aspects of a game to ensure complete fairness

questions.question: In a school disciplinary committee, who represents the Lokpal's role?
questions.explanation: Lokpal acts like a neutral committee that investigates complaints fairly, follows rules, and recommends action while remaining impartial.
questions.analogy: Like a neutral disciplinary committee that investigates complaints and recommends fair actions

questions.question: The UPSC Personality Test is just a casual interview with no serious evaluation.
questions.explanation: Personality Test seriously evaluates judgment, communication, ethics, and suitability through structured panel interviews and situational judgment.
questions.analogy: Like a comprehensive interview that seriously evaluates attitude and ethical judgment

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of PAC reviewing CAG reports?
questions.explanation: Public Accounts Committee reviews CAG reports to demand explanations from officials and recommend corrective actions for identified problems.
questions.analogy: Like a council reviewing an audit and demanding explanations for any issues found

questions.question: During elections, what should polling day conduct be like?
questions.explanation: Model Code of Conduct requires peaceful and orderly conduct on polling day, with parties helping ensure safe and free voting for all citizens.
questions.analogy: Like maintaining peaceful and orderly behavior during class elections

questions.question: How many prosecution sanctions did Lokpal grant out of the complaints processed?
questions.explanation: Lokpal granted prosecution sanction in 6 cases out of the 2,320 defect-free complaints registered, showing careful consideration.
questions.analogy: Like a committee carefully deciding to recommend serious action in only 6 out of many cases

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body ensures that democracy works 'for everyone, not just a few'?
questions.explanation: All constitutional bodies together ensure democracy works for everyone by protecting fairness and honesty in government - the referee, watchdog, and honest judges.
questions.analogy: Like a complete fairness team ensuring the game is fair for all players

questions.question: In a family budget allocation, who represents the Finance Commission's approach?
options: Person who takes the largest share
Person who divides resources fairly based on needs
questions.explanation: Finance Commission divides shared resources fairly based on equity, needs, and balanced development, ensuring all levels get appropriate shares.
questions.analogy: Like dividing a family budget fairly based on everyone's needs and circumstances

questions.question: The Lokpal coordinates with agencies like CBI and ED for professional case handling.
questions.explanation: Lokpal coordinates with agencies such as Central Vigilance Commission (CVC), Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI), and Enforcement Directorate (ED) for professional handling of cases.
questions.analogy: Like a committee working with specialized teams to handle complex cases properly

questions.question: What happens to CAG audit reports after they are presented?
options: They trigger legislative review and accountability
questions.explanation: CAG reports trigger legislative review by committees like PAC, which summons officials and recommends corrective actions, starting the accountability process.
questions.analogy: Like an audit report that starts a review process to fix problems and prevent recurrence

questions.question: A candidate wants to become a civil servant. What should they focus on according to UPSC's merit-based principle?
questions.explanation: UPSC's merit-based principle means selection depends on actual knowledge, abilities, and performance, not connections or influence.
questions.analogy: Like focusing on actual skills and knowledge to make the team, not who you know

questions.question: What was the final outcome category percentage for Lokpal complaints?
questions.explanation: 41% of complaints fell into 'others' category, showing the broad and varied nature of complaints received by Lokpal.
questions.analogy: Like a committee receiving complaints across many different categories

questions.question: Which Constitutional Body's removal of corruption complaints ensures 'fair play' in government?
questions.explanation: Lokpal ensures fair play by impartially handling corruption complaints, investigating fairly, and enabling prosecution when warranted.
questions.analogy: Like a committee ensuring fair play by handling complaints impartially

questions.question: In a school examination system, who represents the UPSC's comprehensive evaluation?
options: Fair evaluation system testing multiple skills
questions.explanation: UPSC represents a comprehensive evaluation system that tests multiple skills and qualities through different stages to ensure fair selection.
questions.analogy: Like a comprehensive examination system that tests different abilities fairly

questions.question: The Finance Commission works only during election years to influence political outcomes.
questions.explanation: Finance Commission works independently on principles of equity and balanced development, not political timing, to ensure fair resource sharing.
questions.analogy: Like a family budget committee that works based on needs, not timing

questions.question: How do Constitutional Bodies work together to protect democracy? Provide a comprehensive explanation using the referee, watchdog, and fair judge analogies.
questions.correct_answer: Constitutional Bodies work as a team: ECI acts as referee ensuring fair elections and peaceful campaigns; CAG acts as watchdog auditing government spending and reporting to PAC for accountability; UPSC acts as fair judge selecting capable civil servants on merit; Lokpal acts as umpire handling corruption complaints fairly; Finance Commission ensures fair resource sharing. Together, they form the 'fairness team' protecting democracy by ensuring power is used responsibly, transparently, and for everyone's benefit, not just a few.
questions.explanation: Constitutional Bodies collectively form India's 'fairness team' - each acting as specialized umpires in different domains (elections, spending, hiring, complaints, resource sharing) to protect democratic values and prevent misuse of power. They ensure accountability, transparency, and merit-based governance.
questions.analogy: Like a complete sports officiating team with referees, judges, umpires, and scorekeepers ensuring fair play in all aspects of the democratic game
